body:
On 3. mai 2010, at 14.36, Matevž Markovič wrote: 
 
> Since I am still an amateur in the Java language, I want to practice 
> as much as possible. Not long ago I came along with an idea, that I 
> want to write a application (Swing application), from which one will 
> be able to choose a file and safely delete it (e.g. rename,delete, 
> overwrite 35-times, possibly less). 
 
I'm not really sure if this is guarateed to work on all Java implementations, but you could try to open the file for random access (http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/io/RandomAccessFile.html), then write random data to the entire contents of the file before you delete. It might even work if you first open, then delete, before writing random data if you prefer that. 
 
But it might be that you are better off finding a command-line tool that handles the secure deletion for you, and create a Swing app that delegates the heavy lifting to the command-line tool. Low-level file system access isn't really one of Java's strong points, as its foucs has always been being cross-platform (Java 7's NIO.2 functionality might fix some of these issues though) . 
 
 
Best regards,
